title: Profile for printing in NinjaFlex on a Makerbot Replicator2

description.text:
I propose you my profile file I use to print in NinjaFlex on my Makerbot Replicator 2 :
Key parameters are :
"rapidMoveFeedRateXY": 90,
"retractDistance": 15,
"retractRate": 25,
"feedrate": 10,
"temperature_disabled": 230.0
If you had success with different parameters, just tell me ! Other details, in French, here : http://www.fabriqueurs.com/test-dimpression-en-ninjaflex-sur-makerbot-replicator-2/
Create a new printing profile and just copy paste the parameters.

comments.text:
I experimented with NinjaFlex for days and got nothing but hideous melted globs. Everyone seems to suggest something different for parameters and I tried them all without success.
Eventually I stumbled across a user named FD_Engineer, who is one of the engineers at Fenner Drives (the people who make NinjaFlex). He suggested printing at 215C and 35mm/s, which was a lot cooler and faster than anyone else seemed to have luck with.
I gave it a shot and what do you know, all of a sudden my prints were coming out beautifully. I guess every printer really is a lot different...
comments.author: hcarter

comments.text:
Thanks for sharing !
I will try this when i'll need to print in Ninjaflex again.

title: Makerfarm Prusa i3 Small Bed Parts replacements

description.text:
NOTE: this isn't a perfect design. It required a significant amount of cleanup afterwards, due to the tolerances on the linear bearing holders not being correct.
But hey, the openSCAD file isn't hard to edit. So these are some improved parts for the Makerfarm Prusa i3 8" (linear bearings, not the v-slot stuff) The y-idler piece has improved nut holders, which make it less annoying to assemble.
The y-carriage belt holder now is a single piece, with a nut trap so that it can be tightened from the top of the carriage.
The bearing holder pieces provide better alignment of the bearings, and so smoother travel. Also, they're easier to install, and again can be tightened from above, with nut traps on the bottom. Note that if these are tightened too much, the bearings could get forced out of alignment.
Additionally, the new bearing holders hold the bed a few mm higher, so there's no risk of the bed colliding with the endpieces that hold the rods.
My print settings weren't ideal, so I won't put them here.  (but the printed parts functioned, so I didn't print again)

author: beefinator

description.text:
I was not satisfied with the Igus bushings on the Shapercube carriage because they were too close and the carriage is a bit too heavy, causing backlash.
I designed this adapter for the LME8LUU long linear bearings that removes any backlash and makes the movement very very smooth.

Print with support material, then remove it. You also need:
  • two LME8LUU bearings
  • four M4 30mm screws
  • four M4 washers
  • four M4 nuts

title: Bottle drain grid for hydroponics (to help prevent clogs)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I use clay pellets in my small hydroponics system and found that occasionally the small ones could cause a clog. I created this simple drain grid to hold back the clay pellets and allow the water to flow at the bottom of a 2-liter bottle.   
Added the 3dponics project to sources as the design was inspired by the usage of the 3dponics drip nozzle with clay pellets I happen to be using. Hopefully this helps prevent some clogs.

• Printed with largest surface facing down.
  • Solid infill was used but you may have some luck with less solid infill.
  • I used transparent 1.75mm ABS as it is what I had most available.

description.text:
Needed a small sprinkler to work with the tubing I was using in my setup. I have also used one of these as a "filter" on the inlet to my small sub pump.
Added the 3dponics sprinkler to the sources as this idea was loosely inspired by that tube style sprinkler.

No Supports. Tube connection facing up.
Solid infill printed in ABS filament.
Printed at 0.2mm and 0.25 mm with no problems.
Will likely work fine with other settings but that is what I have tested.

Prevent the RigidBot PLA spools from rocking back and forth during prints. Similar to yzmoto66's spool holder but with significant mass reduced and nubs at the opposite end to keep the spool on the holder. At 20% fill, this holder is 44g and yzmoto66's holder is 106g. Flip 90 degreed to vertical before printing. Printed on a RigidBot with:
  • 0.254mm layer height
  • 10% fill density
  • 120 mm/s print speed
  • 235 degrees C (PLA)
    • Print took 3 hours and 11 minutes with these settings.

author: hsvtrail

description.text: I personal hate using velcro for my RC Batteries.  You get different CGs  as you don't always put the battery in the same place and you always need to buy velcro for new batteries.  If it peels off (loses it stick at the field) then you need to make sure to have fresh with you.  Maybe not quite that bad, but I don't care for it.  So I made battery boxes that you can slide your batteries in and have the tab hold them in place.  Quick and easy.  Always there and works.  After printing, I use a heat gun to slight bend the tab down for more pressure to hold the batter (on the 3S size which are a bit heavier.).  I also print them in ABS for more flex / spring and durability?  The 3S battery has a tray to glue the battery box on for my crack beaver.  This allows me to mount the battery right between the gear flat and centered.  When you can, glue the side of the box in a corner.  For sides that are not in a corner I use a piece of Blenderm tape glued between the box side and mounting surface.
Funny switch plate modeled in SketchUp, look for the B9Creator-printable STL in the foles, it's got minimal supports and it'S oriented so you can fit 2 on one Table. Cheers!

title: RepRapPro Mendel Carriage for E3D Hotend and capacitive Z-Probe

description.text:
For the X-Carriage i took the one of the Prusa i3 and changed the distance of the bearings to fit the RepRapPro Mendel.
The E3D is shaped into the mount using a clip.
Next to it i added a place for a capacitive probe.
You can see it in action here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MjDHaBO7zic

The sensor is a LJC18A3-H-Z/BX (bought on eBay).
Since it runs on 12V you will need a optocoupler to operate the endstop. To know more about capacitive proximity sensors this video helped me a lot:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PtwquSJ1zgw To set it up I followed the instructions of the Makerfarm tutorial:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6msLOR_EfKc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YpiOsetkIRg If you can read german you finde an more detailed description here:
http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?336,388217 I still did not have the time to translate the howl article to English, sorry.

description.text:
Remix from Flat-footed Mickey Mouse.
Use a long rope or shoelace 100-110 cm.
Braid or hook it to his legs.
Crosses at the neck rope.
Then leave a long piece of rope free overhead and back down through Mickey Mouse.
Make a knot under each shoe.
In the end you make a knot just above the ears.
Make sure you use a brim (5) by the head !
I used 0.2 mm ABS.
Infill 0.1
NO Support

MAKE SURE YOU USE A BRIM WHEN PRINTING THE HEAD !
I used brim 5, otherwise it will not stick on your printing bed.
Have FUN !

title: Center of mass manipulatives for calculus classes

description.text: Calculus classes often learn how to compute the center of mass of a thin plate with varying density. But how can you check that these computations are actually right? It's hard to actually get an example object made precisely enough to verify that the center of mass is in the right place... unless you have access to a 3d printer! This thing is a pair of thin plates with quadratic density functions and marked centers of mass so that you can do the calculation with your class and demonstrate that the math is correct by balancing the print on a string or on your fingertip. This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under DUE-12-45540, 'Motivating First-Year Calculus with Robotics'. For more information about this program, see my webpage.

These are manipulatives for a classroom demonstration of calculating center of mass in a calculus class. Each is a plate in the shape of the area under the parabola 8 - x^2/2 (in cm). The thickness of each plate varies with x to simulate a varying density function: the convex one has "density" given by 5/4 - x^2/16 and the concave one has "density" 1/2 + x^2/16. I'll let you work out the center of mass yourself (honestly, I worry that your students might find this page), but each model has a little loop at the center of mass so that you can suspend it and see that it hangs flat, and a little detent on the bottom face so that you can balance it on your fingertip. These dimensions work well with a classroom document camera-- just remember that if you print in white, you'll probably want to bring a sheet of dark paper to put down on the camera bed to provide contrast. I suggest that you also bring a ruler (marked in cm) so that you can measure the coordinates of the center of mass. You might think that the infill would mess up the center of mass, but it doesn't seem to. I printed at 50% infill on a 5th gen MakerBot, and these balanced quite well. 100% would probably be a little better if you want to spend the filament and the printing time. Or you could experiment with making a hollow version and filling it with hot glue. I included the original Rhino files (.3dm format) in case anyone wants to do a remix which tries this.

title: SPM08 thompson linear bearings mod for i3 EiNSTeiN variant X-ends JBFromOZ remix

description.text:
Further refinement of the X-ends to suit Thompson 4 part linear bearings.
Anyone who has attempted to use Thompson SPM08 linear bearings in place of LM8UU's will know that they are close, but painfully not close enough to LM8UU to be used in place.
I have modded these X-ends to suit the Thompson SPM08 linear bearings (slide like smooth buttery goodness.)
I have included the 608 skate bearing cheek mod, and have also fixed a recently detected issue with the "Friction Fit" on 8mm smooth rod (the existing code called for a 9mm hole!) now my printers are printing properly this was really noticeable.
To solve another issue, I have made the friction fit holes closed off, to facilitate the rod shortening, and X belt tensioning against the X rods instead of being restrained by the Z rods.
I also include some centering caps for the i3 Y bed spangle plate design, previously the Thompson bearings were a little soft, and difficult to get nice action on the Y-rods. these tensioning caps slide over the ends and guide the 4 parts to be concentric on the rod, for a much nicer glide there as well.
I will add the extruder bearing solution once I come up with it!
OpenScad FTW, adjusting and clarifying the interactions of the parts in Prusa's fantastic design,

author: JBFromOZ

description.text: This at first seemed to me the silliest way to use a 3D printer but then I realized in a way it's EXACTLY what the makerbot is great for.  I have an old modified player piano that had one black key damaged (top sheared off) during move in.  The piano is certainly not worth the cost of being pulled apart and a key replaced (I checked, it's a lot), but it has a nice tone so I wanted to fix it without swearing during blues bass line runs.  This is just a replacement for the top part of the key, printed in black ABS and glued on (pretty solidly) with regular poly glue.  So far it's holding...

Constructed a replacement section based on measurements from the adjacent black keys in Rhino3d v.4.0 and saved as an .stl file, printed with black ABS, a 15 second dip in acetone, allowed to dry for 24 hours and then glued to the wood at the shaer point with Pro Bond Poly Glue.  Allow to sit for 6 hours and play.

2008 Renault Megane Dock for Nexus 7 (Air Vent Version)
====
What is it?

Dock for Google Nexus 7 designed specifically to fit a 2008 Renault Megane. The pictures shown are the tech run variant, hence the climate control panel shown, but this should still fit in other version of the 2008 model.
This fits to the dash through use of the central air vents as well as the scalloped clock area, which is also aided through the use of Velcro.
Also includes slot to stick in an NFC tag so that you can have your tablet automatically shift to 'car mode' every time it is inserted into the dock.

Printing
===
Settings

Layer Height: 0.3
Fill Value: 20% plus
Perimeter Thickness: 2-3 layers
Print with Support
Construction
===
What You'll Need

• Double Sided Velcro (20mm width max)
  • NFC Tag (optional)
    Attachment

    Attach the hook side of the your Velcro to the dock on the underside of the arms that extend into the clock scallop, and along the rear cross brace between the arms (see pictures).
    Fill the surface of the inset area for the clock with the soft side of your Velcro to ensure a good stick for your dock.

description.text: My new YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnnw56J_TeOsF4M_F5pPPJQ Are you looking for a fairer faucet? Let me be your angel, Charlie! This is the first revision of a shower head intended to screw on to a standard 1/2" threaded shower pipe. Pressurized water is a tricky thing to deal with; especially with 3D prints. The nozzles on this are designed to keep turbulence low and under adequate pressure, the taper on the business end of the hole should keep the water stream solid. They are pretty small holes so they will likely close up a bit when printing but when you use a pushpin or paperclip to check them, they should be just the right size in the end. UPDATE! I just installed my prototype and D'OH! I had the thread going the wrong direction! Still, I muscled it on and it sealed alright. The holes were closed shut after the print and once the plastic cooled, they were hard to open with a pin. Still, It works pretty darn well! There was some water that seeped through the layers and I'm certain water will become trapped inside the head but if you print at .2 or even .1 mm layer height, print it pretty much solid and maybe dunk it in acetone for a second or two, it should be nice and watertight! I updated the file with the correct thread and fewer/larger holes. Spray away! If you like what I do and want to help me do more, please consider supporting me on my Patreon page! http://www.patreon.com/ErikJDurwoodII Thanks!

1)  Print shower head nozzles-down.  My prototype was printed with a layer height of .27 mm, 20% infill and 3 shells in white ABS plastic.
2)  Use a pushpin or small paperclip to excavate and true the holes of each nozzle.
3)  Press a 1/2" faucet gasket to the mating surface of the interior of the threaded neck.
4)  Layer Teflon piping tape on the threads of the shower pipe.
5)  Firmly thread and twist the shower head on the pipe until you feel it press into the gasket.
6)  Cinch it down with about a quarter-turn of pressure.  Remember this is plastic, don't over-tighten as you can strip the threads or split the layers.

description.text: This is a parametric rim reinforcement for plastic bottles. I made it for hanging bottles in my hydroponics system. The 107mm STL fits my 2L Mountain Dew bottles.

Cut your plastic bottle.
Determine the diameter of the opening. The only way I could find to reliably measure mine was to flatten the opening and measure the length. Then double that to get the circumference. The diameter can be calculated from there.
Edit the SCAD so that 'rim_id' equals your diameter.
Compile. Print.
Fit the reinforcement on the bottle opening.
Poke holes in the bottle inline with the printed holes.
Zip-tie it secure.

Initially, the enlosure was built to reduce noise.  However, it's become a good insulator of heat and humidity.  As a result, less build warpage.  There is a hole on the bottom of the enclosure to vent out the Makerbot power supply.  The top shelf feeds the ABS filament.

The display boards are 20" x 30".  White duct tape is used to hold it together.  The top shelf is display board that sits on pieces of display board taped to the sides of the enclosure. One eighth inch balsa wood reinforces the top shelf to hold weight. The enclosure sits on a work table. There is meshed shelf lining taped and glued in the inner walls of the enclosure for sound deadening.

comments.text: 3DPrintClean is developing an Odor and Ultrafine Particle filtration attachment for DIY enclosures. Would make a great addition. See http://3dprintclean.com/3dprintclean-scrubber.htm - Disclosure, I am the founder of 3DPrintClean.

Spool hanger for XYZ Printing DaVinci 1.0 printer. Hangs off the back of the machine. Has a filament guide to keep the spool from unwinding (I cleaned up the guide hole with a 5/64" or slightly larger drill bit after printing).
Set up the spool direction as shown in the photo, or it WILL unwind incorrectly.
11m of filament used as shown with normal shell thickness and high density.
To install, you have to offset the lid. This can be done by raising the lid 15 degrees then pushing the bottom rear of the lid up and toward the front of the machine as shown in the 4th photo.
Will fit most 3rd party spools 2.5" deep or less.

comments.text: I use a piece of Hardware called XYZeroCart -just Google it. title: Printrbot Plus 2.1 Robust Y Tensioner Assembly

description.text:
As you can see in one of the pics, my little slab of laser cut wood meant to tension the Y axis on my P+ 2.1 was taking a beating, what with a single screw, two dovetails, and a prayer holding it to the upper platform.   
The wood was starting to give way, so I redesigned a printable version that was thick enough to butt up against the back plate of the tray. I also thickened the belt holder and made nut holders to stop them from spinning around when I try to tighten things up.

description.text:
Create fluted solids with arbitrary profiles, swirls and more.
You must have access to Rhino3D and its Grasshopper programming plugin for this to work for you.
The video (http://youtu.be/U4JKHKbO-M4) shows how profile and parameter changes allow you to create any model you can imagine

Grasshopper allows you to take 3D geometry and other input and process it with great flexibility. The downloadable ZIP file includes a Rhino3D model as an example and an accompanying Grasshopper programme file. The grasshopper code expects an arbitrary vessel profile. It then creates a series of of fluted sections that are lofted to create the object. The top and bottom sections are mandatory but you can also specify intermediate sections and specify where they are located on the profile curve. At the moment the code has two intermediate sections that can be enabled or disabled at will. By duplicating the section code block you can add as many as you like...
For each section you can specify the number of flutes, the degree of the curve (sharp or smoother), the offsets between the inside and outside of the flute, the rotation of the section and much more. Just play with the parameter sliders and watch what happens to the model. The video provides some hints.. The code will also generate a solid model from the lofted shell - where this is possible. There is a separate parameter block to specify wall and base thickness. This will not always work well with larger wall thicknesses and order 1 flutes as the Grasshopper offset function can "misbehave" and or create interior walls that are invalid.
For this reason you can export either the solid or the vessel outer skin (and base). If you export the latter, then you can either design your own inner wall - or use a slicer like Simplify3D to just print a single layer (helical) vase. (A fast option for objects where a single wall will do!) A number of examples are depicted and included as STLs. You are genuinely only limited by your imagination. The example file includes a vessel profile in one plane - but if you create this in 3D you will find even more amazing things can be created...

comments.text: Hi—this design looks really awesome! I'm pretty new to Grasshopper. I want to try out this file and experiment with the parameters and so forth. Your notes say that this file "expects an arbitrary vessel profile"—I'm not entirely sure what that means.
comments.author: dgonz

comments.text: If you load the example files you will see. Feed it a vertical curve of your own or use the one already there.... You can make the curve arbitrarily complex in all dimensions and see what happens in real time. The beauty of grasshopper... :-)
comments.author: dgonz

description.text: Made from a scan of the original using the Sense 3d scanner
used a 3d scanner this is a high poly model

I just finished designing and building http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39789 The pain with enclosed cable chains is you can't easily rewire them or replace a link. Here I've made a set with a U section instead of enclosed. It is also easier to clip these open links together than the closed ones. Extras. I've added some "45-x" part which can bend back 45 degrees as well as forwards. Likewise the "22-x" is 22.5 degrees and "9-x" is 9 degrees

I've done two versions of the basic link - one with the top open and the other with the bottom open. You can use these to build a chain with the channel on the inner side or the outer side. You can also alternate them to have the the cable somewhat captive.   
There is also a groove to hold a zip-tie is place.  
My chain has the two lowest movable bottom links reversed compared to the rest.  
There are now parts which can bend back so there is no need to do this anymore.

description.text:
It works!
The extrusions stick out too far for the original design. I altered them to fit. You might only need the screw mount The End stop mount was just extended get out to the end of the longer X-axis extrusions.
I just realized that I put the screw hole on the wrong side (FIXED)!! The X end stop might work in it's place
Thank you for the original design clough42!
I used the UNFIXED VERSION in the pic. I also modified the switch holder to use a zip tie. I will upload the fixes asap.

comments.text: Very cool.  I had noticed the longer extrusions in the photos, but I didn't think about the Z stop being a problem.  I wonder why Colin decided to leave them longer.  Oh...he probably wanted all three axes the same length for convenience and inventory management.  The Y rods had to be extended by more than two inches to get a longer lever arm on the bed.  The X carriage didn't get any wider, so there's extra.

More in the series of asteroid models derived from RADAR data, these are the asteroids 4179 Toutatis (4.5 x 2.4 x 1.9 km) and 4486 Mithra (2-5 km). Data for these asteroids are based on RADAR data archived at the Jet Propulsion Lab (http://echo.jpl.nasa.gov/links.html). Again these will hopefully be part of a hands-on display of data actualization in collaboration with the local NASA office.

Shapes were derived from RADAR data and converted to .obj files, brought into Rhino3D v 4.0, reoriented to print without support structures (although the first 5-6 layers are a bit loose it tightens u prapidly thereafter) and saved as .stl files.  I've been printing in white to see shadow detail but a friend who is an NEO object specialist seemed horrified that I wasn't printing them in black, so I obliged with Mithra.

This thing addresses that pesky issue.

Editted @danepowell's version for a Star Wars feel and adjusted to fit a 600 x 300mm space (24" x 12").
Your resource cards need to be changed to say:
Route - Droid + Moisture
Fighter - Droid + Moisture + Tibanna + Bantha
Capital Ship - 2xTibanna + 3xBacta
Dev Card - Bantha + Tibanna + Bacta
The .svg file has a layer for "cuts" (which are also in red), and a layer for "etching" (in black) so select the layer you want to easily adjust stroke thickness or whatever your cutting program uses to distinguish cuts from etches.

author: byformica

title: FlashForge Creator PRO Filament tube holder

description.text:
Just a simple bracket to bring the filament tubes outwards for easier use, and to prevent the filament from slipping off the spool and getting tangled between it and the machine. It also utilizes the stock filament tube holders for easy installation!
DOES NOT FIT THE NEW 2016 MODELS!!!

The first version is with 6.1mm holes, which were perfectly fine for me, after I cleaned the holes with a 6mm drill bit, by turning it in the holes a few times with my fingers.  
The V2 file is exactly the same part, except it has 6.2mm holes for those who find the smaller holes too small.  
Print it upside up with full supports and a raft for best results. And push the tubes through the holes before you mount the holder on the back of the printer, it's way easier that way!

author: byformica

title: Z-Probe
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a retractable Z-Probe.
With a Z-Probe your Makerbot is able to "auto home" not only X & Y but also the Z axis. This is done by mounting the endstop on your Makerbot in a way it senses the build platform directly (and nearby the real nozzle).
In order to get out of the way during printing, the sense-pin is retractable. Although this is a working thing, especially the software changes are still beta. Both, firmware and ReplicatorG/host software, need to be updated. The extended versions are available as source code on GitHub. For more information (and a sample video), see
http://pleasantsoftware.com/developer/3d/2010/09/14/finding-home/

The design is for use with a Futaba servo S148. That's the servo I found in my junk box. I guess each servo has a different size. So the design might be more a draft for your own design. I plan to try the same thing with a smaller (and cheaper) "micro servo" in the future. I hope I'll find the time to create a parametric OpenSCAD design until then. Since it's still a prototype, the servo is currently glued to the base plate with some hot glue. Both, the new extruder firmware as well as the extended ReplicatorG host software, are available on GitHub. I forked both projects from Makerbot: G3Firmware: http://github.com/zaggo/G3Firmware
ReplicatorG: http://github.com/zaggo/ReplicatorG (ZProbe branch) This is all still in a very early stage, both hardware and software.

author: byformica

title: byFormica.com Liquid Ant Feeder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple, gravity-assisted feeder for ants. Unique design allows the user to allow for a small or large amount of liquid to be accessible. Guard posts on the bottom keep ants from drowning. The posts in the base form a friction fit with the liquid reservoir, so things don't come apart.
~
Assembly:
With the reservoir upside-down, orient the triple guard posts with the base prongs and press down to lock together. Flip the assembly right-side up before rotating the reservoir 45 degrees, if desired, so ants may have better access to the liquid.
~
Use an "n" motion when inverting the liquid-filled assembly, so as to avoid inadvertently losing liquid through the openings. The inertia of the motion will keep the liquid from spilling.

For filament printers:
~
  • Orient reservoir section upside-down
  • Print at very fine setting (10 microns or better)
  • 3 shell
  • 30% infill
  • NO supports
  • YES raft
    ~
    Base section may be printed at standard settings without a raft.

author: spydude119

description.text:
After having serious problems to getting grass nearby some other plants growing on a little terrace in my aquarium I got the idea to 3d print a small stackable grid with small walls. Even the fishes loved to pick on the plants to much...  
Idea / Concept

The idea is to put eg grass plants under a grid and push the grid with the plants into the aquarium ground with the flat side up. So the plants will stay under the grid on every ground. After the plant are enough grown together with the ground the plates can be just picked out or can stay on long term inside the aquarium. Even after plants have grown it should be possible to easily add further plates and connect them with the existing ones.  
Using mesh is a bit unhandy and unflexible but another way. For me in personal it wasn't working as wished. With time its not possible to remove the mesh without taking the plants out.  
Last updates

• 29.07.14 added a big grid for bigger plants, added a basic edge grid
  • 28.07.14 added a fine grid for grass plants

remixed_from.title: Low profile cable chain for lazy people - uppdated for sharper bend radius

title: Wide stable y Axis guide bearing mounts for Creatr and Creatr XL -v8 Final version

description.text:
The right bearing is installed and its a massiv improvement in extruder carriage stiffness.
This mod makes the y carriage a lot stiffer.
I have had 2 Creatr Printers (both where damaged in transport)
I have noted that the y axis is to flexible, i made a 12 mm top mounted bearing to stiffen it up. This helped but the y bearing is still to flexible.
This has a serious effect on accurasy, espesially when printing large collections of parts. The printer bearing drifts, resulting in tilted prints. This mount is much wider and does not allow for any paralell drift.
I will make the left side block once the right sided block is propperly tested.
Printed in PLA 80 deg bed temp and 198 deg c extruder temp.
This part is hard to get right i strongly recomend you make and mount the dual spring loaded extruder before printing these parts.
PS: this is bound to void your warranty, make sure you know what you are doing before making this mod.

PS ou will have to disasemble your printer bearings.
Dont make these adjustments to your printer unless you know what you are doing.
This is bound to void your warranty.
Full instructions will come later

author: Bailey5531

title: byFormica.com Small Ant Farm Formicarium
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
One of the chamber blocks fits in the main housing to create a small formicarium large enough to contain a young or small colony of ants.
~
A 1/8" thick piece of acrylic or clear plastic is needed to complete this piece. The dimensions are 1.633" X 2.212". If you only need one piece, visit www.byformica.com and Contact Us to inquire if plastic pieces are available.
~
Development for this project has been suspended, and the models will be deprecated by a forthcoming design.

Hexagonal Chambers - Best suited for small ants, the depth of the hexagonal chambers may be customized by adding plaster.
~
3-row Chambers - Works best for larger ants that can not fit through the vent openings. Chipboard or cardboard is cut to fit on the vents, so water may be wicked through. The user may also add plaster and dirt fillets to tailor the shape of the chambers.
~
4-row Chambers - Experimental, winding design. Plaster or other barrier should be inserted into the back vents so ants can not crawl through.
~
5-row Chambers - Experimental design for very small ants.
~
~
Main Housing Notes -
  • The hole on the right side is to inject water to humidify the nest.
  • The hollow center is the water reservoir, and should be stuffed with cotton or fibers to wick the water
  • A piece of tape may be stuck on the bottom hole, so water does not leak out
  • The entry/exit hole size will fit 1/2" OD tubing
  • The tunnel joint where the chamber block and main housing meet may need to be filled with plaster, hot glue, or silicone so ants can not crawl through.
    ~
    The chambers may be used as modules for other designs, including larger formicaria, as is illustrated in the gallery.

Umbau eines Velleman K8200 auf ein neues Netzteil: 1x SNT MW100-15 - 15V / 6,7A / 100W
1x 80mm Luefter (Halterung: l-halterung1.stl / l-halterung2.stl)
4x Luefter entkopplung 10x26mm (siehe bild)
1x Wippschalter 30x22mm Da ich ja schon kritisiert wurde warum ich ein zweites Netzeil für die lüfter benutze, hab ich die lüfterhalterung angepasst, somit ist diese option nur Optional und kein muß.
Wenn man den Lüfter nicht über 15V betreiben möchte (geräuschentwicklung wegen höherer drehzahl des Lüfters je nach Lüftermodel) gibt es die möglichkeit über das unten genannte Netzteil.

(passende Halterung l-halterung-netz1.stl / l-halterung-netz2.stl)

comments.text: Das Originale hat sich bei längerer druckzeit immer überhitzt und hat sich dann von selbst abgeschalten, so das das gedruckte teil dann kaputt war, deshalbt hab ich mich entschieden es zu tauschen und hatte seit dem keine ausfälle mehr.
comments.author: morphygee

comments.text: Ja das stimmt, da das große netzteil mit 15V läuft, hätte es wohl den lüfter auf dauer zerstört und für später kann man auch noch andere lüfter mit dran hängen
comments.author: morphygee

comments.text:
Nix für ungut, aber:
mir ist in meiner gesamten Karriere noch kein Lüfter untergekommen der durch moderate Überspannung das zeitliche segnet.
Er läuft halt bischen schneller und ist u.U. (je nach Qualität) bischen lauter ...
Wenn's denn unbedingt 12V für den Lüfter sein müßen, tut's ein 7812 Spannungsregler auch, kostet paar Cent und fertig.
Ein seperates Netzteil halte ich da schon bischen für Overkill, da das ja schließlich auch noch Verlustleistung produziert und mit solch einem Lüfterchen doch gradezu unterfordert ist ;-)
comments.author: m4uli

comments.text:
Hallo BerndJM,
danke für den Tipp und das mim 7812 Spannungsregler is natürlich noch besser da stimme ich Ihnen zu nur muss ich dazu sagen das nicht jeder ein Elektrofachmann ist und die einzelnen Komponenten kennt, so wie Sie :-).
Ich habe extra einen leisen Lüfter besorgt, da ich den Lärm mindern möchte und nicht über höhere drehzahl eventuell wieder steigere somit werd ich daran nun nichts mehr ändern und 7€ für das kleine Netzteil ist denk ich mal jetzt auch nicht viel ;)
Mfg Uwe
comments.author: BerndJM

comments.text:
Man kann auch ganz simpel 4x1N4001 Diode in Reihe vor den lüfter hängen und ihn mit ans netzteil hängen wenn er denn leise sein soll. Ist einfach und billig, Die Spannung am Lüfter sollte grob Überschlagen mit 4 Dioden bei 11,6V- 11,7V liegen, wer es noch leiser will einfach eine weitere dazuhängen in Reihe.
Btw. Ein Spannungsregler sollte nicht ohne Kühlkörper verbaut werden.

aber ein weiteres Netzteil "nagt" ja auch (unnötigerweise) bischen an der Stromrechnung rum ;-))

The banana allowed humanity to introduce a new standard in measuring devices. The banana has been established as a measure of length on March 30th 2005. Since then it became more and more popular as a reference length, gaining a large amount of enthusiasts who wish to see the banana as well established as the meter or inch, and maybe even as a new standard to unite the entire world in the same unit of measurement. This banana will help you become part of this movement. The scale on the banana helps to relate the metric system to the bananic scale. The scale is divided in 1cm and 2mm lines, which are labeled up to 10cm (but still continuing the lines). Banana gif: http://i.imgur.com/HhAk5Ig.gif

Print the banana scale and start measuring.  
My print time was 3h 03min and it used 9.89 m of filament.

title: Big Knobs, Knurled and Labeled, with a Set Screw

description.text:
This file is a mash up of the "LCD Knob" (www.thingiverse.com/thing:51020) by Mrrocketman, with some mods to make it useful on my 6-axis Stewart platform. My changes:
  • add relief under the know for mounting hardware,
  • add labelling (using the write.scad library) to identify the axis
  • add a set-screw hole to hold the knob onto the shaft
  • changed the shaft diameter to 1/4"
    • Mrrocketman's knob was licensed as Creative Commons - Public Domain Dedication, and so it this one. The openSCAD display works slowly on this object. I am using a middle-aged Intel i7 machine (3.2 GHz), and it takes 4 seconds to update the display.

This is a structural construction kit.
It uses a natural set of construction blocks which can fill/divide space.
These blocks are based on natural basic crystal structures with high symmetries. This makes the construction kit more direction independent then conventional ones.

Generate more building blocks (& couplers bricks) by entering the
coordinates of the local nearest neighbours. (Only if the entered nearest neighbours are correctly taken from a proper crystal structure the resulting body will form a solitary space filler.)
|
A web seach revealed this strongly related kit:
http://www.georgehart.com/rp/FCC.html

The basic blocks are the Wiegner-Seitz cells of the following crystal lattices
bcc - body centered cubic
fcc or ccp - face centered cubic or cubic closed packed
hcp - hexagonal close packed
some other voroni cells (e.g. one of a diamond atom) are also included

In atomically precise products such blocks can incorporate diverse basic functions and be used as recomposable microcomponents that can form diverse metamaterials.
Choosing these shapes might be desirable because of the ease to reason about them and their good physical properties.
|
E.g. in bcc cells:
Easy reasoning:
  • cube faces - kartesian
  • octahedral faces - normal to diamond bonds (choosing a main crystal orientation for the housing structure might be sensible)
    |
    Good properties:
  • not too anisotropic
  • edges have no sharp only oblate angles
  • surfaces of aggregates form pockets so Van-der-Waals assembly can easily be used (Van-der-Waals forces can be pretty strong - way stronger than most would intuitively expect)

This is a normal watering can (with a slightly quirky design). However, I designed it really just so that I can print it in a very small size to use on my succulents that shouldn't have very much water. A miniature watering can would make delivering small amounts of water to these arid plants easier. The entire object is hollow except the solid handle. The opening for the water to flow out when watering is small to avoid accidental over watering of succulents. This was made with 123D design and meshmixer.

title: Robo3d 50mm Fanduct (Stock J-Head and E3D-V6)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Annular cooling duct for Robo3d printer with stock j-head hot end. (The new one comes with the hexagon hot end this is not designed for that but if someone wants to print it and check the fitting I can make an adjusted version to fit. Or for the E3D v5 and v6) Designed for 50mm fan for increased airflow(stock fan is 40mm)
Please check the instructions
:EDIT: I've added files for and adjusted version that should fit with the E3D V6. I'm printing them now will adjust the files depending of the results
:EDIT 2: I've noticed the bracket tends to sag, causing the duct to drag on prints. I've included a new version of the bracket with a clip that holds it more securely to the x-carriage
Inspired by: Fan duct to M90 v12mm by Aleksxx
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:379541

You will need to change out the X end stop bolt on the carriage to a 25mm long bolt. The stock bolt is too short with this installed.  
If you're using Cura, I recommend support settings for the duct to Lines with 1.5mm X/Y clearance and whatever else your preferred setting are. Rotate the duct so the lines run parallel to the duct. This will prevent support from being built inside the ring where you cant get to it and makes it so you can pull them all out with pliers. If you use a different slicer you can base your support setting on this to achieve similar results.  
If your having spacing issues with the height of the duct not clearing the print head nozzle you can adjust the Z scaling non uniformly. I've tried up to 5% taller and shorter and it fits fine. I suspect you could go as far as 10%.  
If you have the old print bed on drawer slides, the bolts sticking through on the y+ side of the bed can interfere with the fan duct if you're printing near the edge of the bed. For now if you're using this print near the front of the bed, and I'll re-model the duct for clearance of those bolts.  
When homing the print head, the duct will also contact a bolt. There should be enough flex in the duct that it can home fine, but depending on the starting G-Code in your preferred slicer as it moves from home to start the print it can drag the duct over that bolt. If this is happening add this "G1 Z10.0 F{travel_speed} ;raise head 10mm" to the custom start G code after it home's the axis. I use Cura, not sure if other slicers can use "F{travel_speed}" so if not you can use "F50" or whatever other speed you prefer by adjusting the number.

This extruder is a modified version from the Kossel mini Delta 3d printer. By separating the printed parts into 3 instead of the original one piece, the feeding of the filament is much easier now.
Work with:
8mm or 10mm push fit connector
M3 25mm bolt x 3
M3 35mm (or 30mm) bolt x 1
M3 nut x 1
M3 washer x 6
M4 10mm spring x 1
M5 20mm bolt x 1
M5 nut x 1
625ZZ bearing x 1

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears

title: gear reducer for common 5-6v high speed low torque motor

description.text:
PLEASE USE THE "ROTATED" PARTS OR ROTATE THEM YOURSELF IF YOU RECOMPILE/EXPORT IF NECESSARY.
I wanted to make use of some small motors from old electronics.
It turns out you can find at least two ~5V high speed motors in old CD drives. They have slightly different mounting holes (an yours may be completely different) but I've made this to fit both.
The design consists of a push (mallet) fit small gear which turns a larger gear secured to an m4 bolt. A second small gear secured to that m4 bolt then turns a second large gear, resulting in a ~5x reduction. I included the gear script by GregFrost that I used to fit the gears as well as the custom scad file I used to tweak them.

You should be able to assemble this with 4 m4 (624) bearings, 2 ~40mm m4 bolts, some m4 nuts and some ~40mm m3 bolts and nuts.
It fits well with (and I made it specifically for) my peristalitic pump (thing:409612).
Let me know if you have any questions/issues. The peripump definitely works, but I'm assembling the gear reducer for the first time now.

I know there are tons of spool holders on here but I thought with all the different spools out there, there is a need for customizable spool holders. PLEASE USE THE "ROTATED" PARTS OR ROTATE THEM YOURSELF IF YOU RECOMPILE/EXPORT IF NECESSARY  
I needed a peristaltic pump and wanted to use a motor from some old electronics. I geared it down with my motor gear reducer (thing:409598) and attached it to the output.  
The peripump itself definitely works (with a hand drill) but I'm currently assembling the gear reducer and will test it shortly.
the pump uses 4 m4 bolts to hold the bearings in place, 1 longer ~40mm m4 bolt for the drive shaft, a few m4 nuts, and a few 20mm m3 bolts to hold it together (it secures nicely to my gear reducer).

comments.text: It's not too foamy and I'd guess it gives mild flow at 20-30mL/min at 2-300rpm. I haven't gotten around to trying to test it (it's difficult enough to print gears precise enough that these weak motors can handle moving them)
